subject: Learning
title: Sumerian Scribal Schools
description: A quick win: understand Sumerian Scribal Schools.

hook.text: The world's first schools appeared 5,000 years ago in Mesopotamia. Students learned to write on clay.

buildup.text: Sumerian scribal schools, called edubba, trained boys to become record-keepers for temples and palaces.

discovery.text: Students spent years copying cuneiform tablets. Rote repetition was the only teaching method.

twist.text: Discipline was brutal. Tablets describe beatings for tardiness, poor handwriting, and speaking without permission.

climax.text: Yet these schools created literacy itselfâ€”a technology that would transform every civilization after.

punchline.text: The first classrooms were harsh. The invention was priceless.

quiz.question: What were Sumerian edubba schools designed to train?
options: Scribes who could keep records in cuneiform
